conclusion: Millikan proved the quantization of electric charge by observing the motion of oil droplets, awarded Nobel Prize in Physics in 1923.
The figure illustrates the principle of the Millikan oil-drop experiment with two metal plates and oil droplets acquiring electric charges.
Two spherical oil droplets, A and B, each with mass m0, fall with uniform velocity through distance h1 within time t.
Voltage U is applied across the plates, A continues to fall, B moves upwards with uniform velocity, rises through distance h2 in time t.
B merges with A to form a new droplet, continues to move until reaching uniform velocity.
Air resistance on a droplet is given by f=km^(1/3)v, air buoyancy is negligible, gravity is g.
Image depicts two large metal plates with a small hole in the upper plate, droplets A and B on the same vertical line.
Calculate distances h1 and h2 using h = 1/2gt^2, thus h1 = 1/2gv^2t^2 and h2 = 1/2gv^2t^2.
Since B rises the same distance h2 as A falls h1 in the same time, h1 = h2.
Net force F on droplet is zero: F = mg - kv = 0, therefore mg = kv.
Using v = 1/2gt^2 for uniform velocity, substitute v in mg = kv: mg = k(1/2gt^2).
Simplify mg = 1/2kgt^2 to find k: k = 2mg/gt^2.
